I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Transport  Connections  in  Northern  Mountainous 
Provinces Project.1  
 
2. 
Under  the  project,  about  304  kilometers  (km)  of  provincial  roads  in  six  northern 
mountainous  provinces  of  Viet  Nam  will  be  rehabilitated.2 These  provinces  have  high  rates  of 
poverty  and  large  ethnic  minority  populations.  The  road  network  consists  predominantly  of 
mountainous,  unpaved,  narrow  roads,  and  many  sections  are  impassable  during  the  rainy 
season.  Project  roads  have  been  selected  through  project  preparatory  technical  assistance 
(TA)3 based on social and economic indicators4 to maximize development benefits and impacts. 
The  time  and  cost  of  traveling  from  mountainous  remote  areas  to  social  infrastructure  will  be 
reduced, and the economic activities along the roads will be increased. The project is consistent 
with the strategic priorities of the country strategy and program, which emphasizes investments 
in infrastructure development for pro-poor economic growth.5 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The  northern  mountainous  provinces  of  Viet  Nam  have  developed  at  a  much  slower 
pace than the rest of the country. The project area had 30% of the population living in poverty in 
2009, which is far above the 11% average for the country. Gross domestic product per capita in 
the  northern  mountainous  provinces  was  $400  in  2008,  compared  to  the  national  average  of 
$1,070.  Ethnic  minorities  typically  inhabit  the  more  mountainous  and  less  accessible  areas  of 
the provinces, and account for 69% of the project area’s population.6 The income level of ethnic 
minorities is below average. Women are involved mainly in agricultural activities, and transport 
their products to sell in local markets. Poor access to markets as well as to health, education, 
and other government services is a major constraint on socioeconomic development.  
 
4. 
The  government  recognizes  that  development  of  the  northern  region  of  Viet  Nam  has 
lagged  behind  the  rest  of  the  country.  The  government’s  socioeconomic  development  plan7 
identifies lack of rural infrastructure in the region as a constraint on effective poverty reduction. 
In support of government efforts to meet poverty reduction objectives, the country strategy and 
program  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  supports  initiatives  targeted  at  the  northern 
mountainous  region  to  address  the  high  levels  of  general  and  food  poverty.  Planned 
improvements along the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) corridors are also expected to bring 
increased economic and employment opportunities to the region. The project areas have strong 
demographic and economic relations with the cities that will be connected by the GMS Noi Bai–
Lao Cai Highway and the GMS Ha Noi–Lang Son Expressway, and the project will improve the

5. 
Road  travel  is  the  dominant  transport  mode  in  Viet  Nam.  The road  network  comprises 
more than 256,000 km, of which the vast majority (216,000 km) are provincial and local roads. 
These  are  mostly  in  poor condition—about  52% of the  network  is  unpaved,  and  about  16%  of 
local  population  does  not  have  access  to  an  all-season  road.8 Unpaved  roads  often  become 
impassable  during  the  rainy  season,  and  ordinary  automobiles  cannot  pass  along  the  project 
roads  for  140  days  in  a  year.9 The  poor  road  conditions  contribute  to  accidents  as  well  as 
pavement  damage  due  to  vehicle  overloading.  The  condition  of  the  roads  discourages 
investments  in  the  region,  making  it  difficult  for  agricultural  production  to  expand  beyond 
subsistence farming, or for other industries to develop.  
 
6. 
Road  maintenance  in  Viet  Nam  is  less  than  optimal,  mainly  due  to  insufficient  budget 
and low capacity of operation and maintenance companies.10 The Ministry of Transport (MOT) 
defines  road  maintenance  activities  as  regular  maintenance,  periodical  repair,  and emergency 
repair. 11  The  National  Assembly  approved  establishment  of  a  road  maintenance  fund  in 
November 2008. The fund was expected to provide more stable and sufficient budget for road 
maintenance but the government is facing difficulties securing sufficient revenue and has not yet 
formulated implementation details.  
 
7. 
There is also a need to reduce the life-cycle cost of roads, including both development 
and maintenance costs, as funds to cover the large demand for both road rehabilitation and new 
roads  are  limited.  ADB  is  providing  policy  and  advisory  TA  for  the  MOT,  which  includes  a 
component to  develop  design  guidelines  to  allow  flexible application  of road  classification.12 At 
present,  the  same  road classification  and  corresponding  design  standards  are  usually  applied 
from  the  beginning  to  the  end  points  of  a  road,  regardless  of  varying  traffic  demand  and 
conditions of the road sections. Flexible application of road classification is expected to reduce 
life-cycle costs and improve sustainability of local roads.13 Some roads under the project will be 
designed based on guidelines to be developed through the TA.  
 
8. 
Most  of  the  project  roads  are  in  areas  vulnerable  to  climate  impacts,  and  the 
mountainous  terrain  (and,  therefore,  the  local  economy)  is  prone  to  natural  disaster  risks. 
Frequent  flash  floods  and  road  closures  have  negative  economic  and  social  impacts  on  road 
users  and  residents,  and  these  impacts  are  expected  to  increase  due  to  climate  change.  The 
government approved the National Target Program to respond to climate change in 2008.14 The 
MOT  approved  its  action  plan  toward  the  National  Target  Program  for  seven  subsectors 
including  road  transport  in  2011.15 Provincial  people’s  committees  (PPCs)  are  preparing  local 
action  plans  based  on  the  National  Target  Program.  However,  past  and  current  assistance 
focuses more on coastal areas than the northern mountainous provinces.16

increasingly  important  as  the  government  decentralized  the  responsibilities  for  implementation 
of  official  development  assistance  programs  to  provincial  governments  by  a  decree  in  2006.17 
The project will be implemented directly by the PPCs, unlike previous projects where the MOT 
acted  as  an  executing  agency.  To  efficiently  coordinate  and  monitor  implementation  by  six 
provincial  project  management  units  (PPMUs)  under the  PPCs,  a  joint  coordination committee 
(JCC) has been established upon the Prime Minister’s authorization. This direct implementation 
arrangement  will  enhance  project  ownership  and  encourage  local  government  participation  in 
implementation,  but  it  imposes  the  need  for  some  initial  support  for  procurement,  financial 
management, and other capacity building needs. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

10. 
The impact of the project will be reduced poverty in the project areas. The outcome will 
be improved and reliable road connectivity in the project areas. The project targets 12 provincial 
roads in six northern mountainous provinces in Viet Nam: Bac Kan, Cao Bang, Ha Giang, Tuyen 
Quang, Yen Bai, and Lao Cai provinces. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

The  project  has  three  outputs:  (i)  priority  provincial  roads  totaling  304  km  will  be 
11. 
rehabilitated, including the sections for which design guidelines developed through the TA and 
climate-proofing  measures  developed  through  the  grant  component  are  applied; 18  (ii)  the 
capacity  of  PPC  staff  to  manage  potential  climate  change  impacts  will  be  increased;  and  (iii) 
potential  social  problems19 among  vulnerable  people,  especially  women  and  ethnic  minorities, 
will be prevented and mitigated. 
 
12. 
A  grant  component  for  integrating  climate  change  adaptation  to  transport  will  provide 
(i) capacity building of provincial department of transport (PDOT) staff, (ii) vulnerability mapping 
of  project  roads  selected  for  rehabilitation,  (iii)  identification  and  prioritization  of  adaptation 
approaches,  (iv)  detailed  design  to  increase  the  resilience  of  the  project  roads  to  climate 
change, and (v) policy strengthening and coordination.20

ADB will finance 73% of the project cost. The ADB financing is through the Asian Development 
Fund.  ADB  will  finance  (i)  civil  works,  (ii)  project  coordination  consulting  and financial  auditing 
services to be engaged by the JCC, (iii) equipment, and (iv) contingencies related to items (i)–
(iii)  and  financial  charges  during  development.  ADB  will  finance  taxes  and  duties  for  project 
coordination  and  financial  auditing  consulting  services  and  equipment  (about  $0.5  million)  to

under  the  ADB  loan.  The  climate  change  adaptation  component  for  €2  million  (equivalent  to 
$2.78  million22)  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Nordic  Development  Fund  (parallel

16. 
The executing agencies will be the six PPCs. The implementing agencies will be the six 
PPMUs  under  the  PPCs.  PPMUs  are  established  in  all  provinces  and  are  staffed  with 
counterpart personnel mostly seconded from the PDOTs.  
 
17. 
Based  on  authorization  from  the  prime  minister,  the  Bac  Kan  PPC  issued  an  official 
decision to establish a JCC for the project.23 The JCC will coordinate and monitor the activities 
of  six  PPMUs  and  report  these  activities  to  ADB  with  support  from  a  project  coordination 
consultant  (PCC).  The  JCC’s  primary  tasks  will  include  (i)  submitting  PPC-endorsed  initial 
environmental examinations (IEEs), resettlement plans, gender action plan (GAP), and gender 
action and ethnic minority development plans (GAEMDPs) to ADB for review, concurrence, and 
posting  on  ADB’s  website;  (ii)  monitoring  compliance  with  policies  and  loan  covenants  and 
reporting  the  status  to  ADB;  (iii)  assisting  PPMUs  with  their  procurement  activities;  (iv) 
coordinating  with  PPMUs  in  updating  and  implementing  environmental  management  plans 
(EMPs), resettlement plans, GAP, and GAEMDPs; (v) coordinating with PPMUs and ministries 
in  applying  flexible  design  guidelines  and  climate  change  adaptation  measures;  (vi)  preparing 
and  submitting  audited  financial  statements  of  six  PPMUs;  and  (vii)  providing  training  for 
capacity development of PPMUs. The Bac Kan PPMU will be authorized to carry out such tasks 
as signing contracts and withdrawal applications on behalf of the JCC.  
 
18. 
All  procurement  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement capacity of PPMUs is assessed as fair, with 
previous  experience  on  ADB  and  other  externally  funded  projects  although  the  MOT  was  the 
overall  executing  agency  for  them.  The  threshold  for  national  competitive  bidding  is  set  at 
$5 million.  Lessons  from  previous  provincial  road  projects  suggest  that  small  civil  works 
packages  are  inefficient  to  manage.  The  civil  works  will  be  divided  into  23  packages  (an 
average of  $3.4  million  per  package),  based not  on  availability  of  local  contractors  or  ordinary 
size  of  PDOTs’  other  projects  but  on  topographic  and  other  relevant  parameters.  They  will  be 
procured by national competitive bidding. 
 
19. 
For  the  consulting  services  financed  by  ADB  funds,  consultants  will  be  selected  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time) while the cofinancier’s guidelines will apply for the grant component. The Bac Kan PPMU, 
on behalf of the JCC, will recruit an international consulting firm as a PCC by quality- and cost-
based  selection  (QCBS)  using  a  quality–cost  ratio  of  90:10  and  full  technical  proposals  with 
advance  contracting  and  retroactive  financing  for  $1  million.  The  high  quality–cost  ratio  is 
proposed  because  of  the  complexity  of  the  project  implementation  arrangement,  where  six 
executing  agencies  will  work  under  coordination  of  the  JCC  and  administration  of  ADB,  thus 
greater  priority  is  given  to  the  quality  of  the  PCC  over  cost.  The  impact  of  the  consultant’s

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

21.  Many provincial roads across the country are deteriorating because of design standards 
that are inadequate to support traffic loads, and inadequate routine maintenance. Maintenance 
is  underfunded,  being  at  50%  or  less  of  what  is required for the roads to  be  maintained to  an 
acceptable  standard.  The  major  problem  affecting  road  maintenance  funding  is  the  continuing 
high  investment  on  new  works.  Viet  Nam  is  in  the  process  of  establishing  road  maintenance 
funds  to  improve  road  conditions  by  allocating  stable  and  sufficient  maintenance  funding.  In 
addition,  the  life-cycle  cost  of  roads  for  both  development  and  maintenance  should  be 
minimized to fully utilize the limited available funds. ADB is supporting the MOT through TA to 
develop  modified  guidelines  with  increased  design  flexibility  to  reduce  life-cycle  costs  and 
improve  the  sustainability  of  roads  (footnote  12).  The  guidelines  and  the  outputs  of  the  grant

B. 

Economic and Financial 

22. 
The project will directly benefit transport users and communities in the six provinces and 
the  main  benefits  are  derived  from  improved  accessibility  to  better,  safer,  faster,  and  more 
reliable  transport  connections.  These  improved  transport  connections  will  increase  economic 
activities in the project areas and provide the communities with improved access to markets and 
social  services.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  the  project  roads  ranges  from 
16.3% to 40.8%, and the economic net present value ranges from $0.65 million to $19.6 million. 
Overall, the project has a weighted average EIRR of 25.6% and economic net present value of 
$5.3 million. The sensitivity analysis shows a relatively stable EIRR. The lowest EIRR would be 
13.3%  if  the  benefits  were  reduced  by  20%.  The  analysis  also  indicates  that  the  EIRR  of  all 
project  roads  would  be  higher  than  12%  despite  a  20%  increase  in  project  costs.  Detailed 
results of the analysis are described in the economic and financial analyses.25  
 
C. 

Governance 

23. 
A governance assessment was carried out as part of the due diligence. The assessment 
covered  the  capacities  of  the  PPMUs,  focusing  on  financial  management,  institutional  issues, 
policies  and  procedures,  and  risks.  Governance  of  the  PPCs  will  be  improved  to  meet  the 
increasing responsibility under decentralization. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended 
to date) was explained to and discussed with the government and the PPCs of Bac Kan, Cao 
Bang,  Ha  Giang,  Tuyen  Quang,  Yen  Bai,  and  Lao  Cai  provinces.  In  addition,  the  provincial 
governments  agreed  to  implement  other  measures  to  strengthen  governance.  These  include 
establishing a grievance redress mechanism for project-related issues, including corruption, and 
creating a project website at the JCC to disclose information on procurement and other project-
related matters to the public. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are 
described in the project administration manual.26 

 
Poverty and Social 

D. 

24. 
The primary source of income of most households in the project area is agriculture. The 
major ethnic groups in the project area are Dao, Hmong, Nung, and Tay. In 2008, the incidence 
of poverty in Cao Bang Province was 39%, in Tuyen Quang it was 38%, in Bac Kan 31%, in Ha 
Giang 28%, in Yen Bai 24%, and in Lao Cai 21%.  
 
25. 
The  project  is  categorized  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  To  ensure  that  women 
and ethnic minorities equally share project benefits and adverse impacts are mitigated, the GAP 
has  been  prepared  for  Yen  Bai  Province,  while  combined  GAEMDPs  have  been  prepared  for 
the provinces of Bac Kan, Cao Bang, Ha Giang, Tuyen Quang, and Lao Cai. The plans include 
the  following  actions  and  strategies:  (i)  road  hazards  will  be  identified  and  removed;  road  and 
traffic  signs,  road  safety  warnings,  and  pedestrian  crossings  will  be  installed  in  strategic 
locations;  and  light  poles  and  speed  bumps  will  be  installed  at  requested  locations;  (ii)  during 
construction,  civil  works  contractors  will  hire  at  least  20%–30%  local  unskilled  labor,  and  of 
these  at  least  50%  will  be  female; male and  female unskilled  workers (regardless of  ethnicity) 
will receive equal pay for equal work; and separate male and female latrines and basic facilities

change impacts  will  integrate  gender  issues,  and 25%  of the  PPMU  staff  attending  adaptation

disaggregated data will be collected during implementation and monitoring.  
 
E. 

Safeguards 

26. 
The  project  is  classified  category  A  under  indigenous  peoples  based  on  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  ethnic  minorities  in  the  remote  areas,  especially  in 
those  that  are  difficult  to  access  by  road  during  the  rainy  season,  are  particularly  poor.  Road 
improvement  will  greatly  benefit the  ethnic minority  groups  but  there are also increased  social 
risks.  As  indicated  in  para.  25,  GAEMDPs  for  Bac  Kan,  Cao  Bang,  Ha  Giang,  Tuyen  Quang, 
and Lao Cai provinces have been designed in a culturally and linguistically gender-responsive 
way.  The  plans  will  be  translated  into  ethnic  minority  languages  since  a  critical  source  of 
vulnerability  among  women  from  ethnic  minority  groups  is  language,  which  isolates  these 
women and reduces income-generating opportunities. Data disaggregated by ethnic group will 
be collected during implementation and monitoring.   
 
27. 
Resettlement  impacts  are  not  significant  and  are  classified  category  B.  Although  about 
4,700  households  are  affected  by  land  acquisition,  no  households  are  losing  10%  or  more  of 
their total productive assets. Impacts on structures are limited as houses and shops will be only 
partially  affected.  There  will  be  no  impacts  on  common  property  resources,  and  access  to 
properties  and  economic  opportunities  will  not  be  restricted  during  project  construction  and 
operation.  Key  information  in  the  resettlement  plans  has  been  disclosed  to  the  affected 
households  through  distribution  of  information  leaflets  in  Vietnamese  or  local  ethnic  minority 
languages  during  market  days  in  the  communes  prior  to  submission  to  ADB  for  review  and 
concurrence.   
 
28. 
The  project  has  been  classified  category  B  under  environment.  Results  of  the  IEEs 
conducted  for  each  province  showed  that  the  proposed  road  improvement  works  will  result  in 
minor  environmental  impacts.  The  biological  environment  is  dominated  by  agriculture, 
production forests, and tree plantations around most stretches of the project roads. None of the 
project roads traverses buffer or core zones of ecologically or culturally protected areas. While 
the  whole  of  project  road  176A  in  Ha  Giang  Province  is  within  the  Dong  Van  Karst  Plateau 
Geopark—an  area  recognized  by  the  United  Nations  Educational,  Scientific  and  Cultural 
Organization 
landscape  and  geological 
significance—no significant adverse impacts are expected as the project will be undertaken on 
an existing road that only requires minimal widening (up to 1 meter). During the detailed design 
phase, the Ha Giang PPMU will consult the geopark’s management board and will compile the 
requisite project report to obtain UNESCO’s concurrence.  
 
The adverse environmental impacts will be largely experienced during construction due

moderate disturbance to the surrounding areas provided the EMPs are fully implemented. The 
EMPs  provide  mitigation  measures  and  monitoring  activities  to  avoid  or  reduce  anticipated 
negative project impacts.

F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

32. 
Key project risks include (i) inadequate budget allocation for maintenance of the project 
roads, (ii) damage to the project roads from extreme weather events and overloaded vehicles, 
(iii)  cost  overrun, (iv)  insufficient  capacity  of  PPMUs,  and  (v)  delay caused  by incorporation of 
outputs  from  the  TA  (for  flexible  design  guidelines)  or  grant  component  (for  climate  change 
adaptation).  The  government  has  agreed  to  implement  mitigating  measures  to  address  these 
risks. Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in 
the risk assessment and risk management plan.27

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

33. 
The  government  and  the  PPCs  of  Bac  Kan,  Cao  Bang,  Ha  Giang,  Tuyen  Quang,  Yen 
Bai, and Lao Cai provinces have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform 
to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the project 
administration manual and loan documents. 
 
34. 
The  government  and  the  PPCs  of  Bac  Kan,  Cao  Bang,  Ha  Giang,  Tuyen  Quang,  Yen 
Bai, and Lao Cai provinces have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the  project, which 
are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement.  
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

35. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various

Connections  in  Northern  Mountainous  Provinces  Project  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources 
with  an  interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per 
annum  thereafter;  for  a  term  of  32  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  8 years;  and  such  other 
terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and 
project agreements presented to the Board.
